Award.AwardTitle: Building BRIDGES Within the Undergraduate Major in Computer Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, investigators from UNC Charlotte are building a software
infrastructure named ``BRIDGES" (Bridging Real-world Infrastructure
Designed to Goal-align, Engage and Stimulate) to transform student
experiences in computing education. The primary goal of the project is to
improve retention of CS majors, especially at the sophomore level. BRIDGES
facilitates a hands-on experience for solving traditional problems in computer
science using real-world information systems, such as Facebook, Twitter,
Google Maps, etc. BRIDGES is being integrated into two computer science
required courses, the senior capstone course and the sophomore level
data structures and algorithms course, enabling a senior-sophomore bridge.
Sophomore and senior students in these courses will partner in joint lab
sessions to utilize and create new extensions to the BRIDGES infrastructure
to support data structures programming assignments. Sophomores will act as
customers for the new tools and data sets created by seniors and use them in
their course programming assignments. In this manner, BRIDGES will create a
more connected student body by partnering sophomores and seniors, which
should lead to improved student retention and engagement. BRIDGES is
being built using open source and web technologies, promoting easy
dissemination. Two workshops on the BRIDGES system will be held,
involving educators from regional colleges and high schools, including
minority and underrepresented institutions. An additional workshop will be
held associated with a major education conference. Students from the STARS Alliance (an NSF funded Broadening Participation in Computing consortium) will be given access to the learning materials and infrastructure to incorporate into their outreach and teaching activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has resulted in BRIDGES, a software infrastructure that facilitates
solving traditional problems in computer science by providing easy access
to  using real-world data and information systems (such as Facebook,
Twitter, Google Maps, IMDB Actor/Movie data, etc) as part of routine course
assignments.  BRIDGES also  provides visualization capabilities to better
engage students completing traditional and rigorous assignments.
The project targets computer science students at the sophomore level,
a particularly vulnerable point in computer science programs, in order to
improve retention and graduation.

Outcomes from this project include the following:

  1.  The BRIDGES system  is stable and works with 3 programming languages, C++, Python and Java;
  2. BRIDGES has been used in over 11 courses at UNC Charlotte and  through partner instructors in 16 courses at  10 universities external to UNC Charlotte
  3. BRIDGES has been disseminated through conferences, mailing lists, and direct contact.
  4.  Over 1300 students have so far been directly impacted by the BRIDGES software. This impact has been increasing in recent years (nearly 200 student users in Spring 2019).
  5.  BRIDGES has demonstrated knowledge gains in data structures courses when compared non-BRIDGES users of the same course.
  6. Students undergoing courses using the BRIDGES exercises have shown superior performance in 4 follow-on required courses in computer science.
  7. Qualitative Analysis performed on BRIDGES project surveys over 4 years show over 90%  positive responses to BRIDGES.
  8. Surveys of instructors using BRIDGES in their data structures were overall positive, but also noted a moderate amount of learning curve required to use the toolkit.
  9. Two conference publications, numerous demonstrations and presentations and four workshops have resulted from the project.
  10.  Training and mentoring of 10 students (2 PhD, 8 undergraduate) involved in the BRIDGES project; 7 of the undergraduate students have continued into graduate school. Two female students and 1 Latino student were involved in the project.
  11. Peer mentoring  was implemented to  bring  senior level students  to
    connect and mentor  sophomore level data structures students. Overall,  results were mixed and require further investigation.
